facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 2134 of 1970 filed.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 2134 of 1970. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 5, 1970 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in  Indore Bench  in Second Appeal No. 618 of 1964.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated March 5, 1970 of Madhya Pradesh High Court Indore Bench in Second Appeal No. 618 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 5, 1970 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in  Indore Bench  in Second Appeal No. 618 of 1964. Rajendra Chowdhry, for the appellant.

facts.text: Defendants' appeal by special leave against High Court judgment allowing second appeal in partition suit between Muslim family members.

anchor.surface_text: This is a Defendants appeal by Special Leave against the judgment and decree of the High Court of Madhya Pradesh allowing a second appeal in a partition suit between members of a family governed by Muslim law.

facts.text: Defendant-Appellant and Plaintiff-Respondent are sons of Kadir Ali Bohra.

anchor.surface_text: The Defendant- Appellant and the Plaintiff-Respondent are both sons of Kadir Ali Bohra who died on 5-4-1952 leaving behind five sons, a daughter and his widow as his heirs.

facts.text: Kadir Ali Bohra died on 5-4-1952 leaving five sons, a daughter, and widow as heirs.

anchor.surface_text: Kadir Ali Bohra who died on 5-4-1952 leaving behind five sons, a daughter and his widow as his heirs. It appears that Kadir Ali had incurred debts so heavily that all his property would have been swallowed up to liquidate these.

facts.text: Kadir Ali Bohra incurred heavy debts sufficient to swallow all his property.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that Kadir Ali had incurred debts so heavily that all his property would have been swallowed up to liquidate these. Three of his sons, namely, Ghulam Abbas, Defendant No. 1, Abdullah, Defendant No. 2, and Imdad, Defendant No. 3, who had prospered, came to his rescue so that the property may be saved.

facts.text: Ghulam Abbas (Defendant No. 1), Abdullah (Defendant No. 2), and Imdad (Defendant No. 3) paid father's debts to save property.

anchor.surface_text: Three of his sons, namely, Ghulam Abbas, Defendant No. 1, Abdullah, Defendant No. 2, and Imdad, Defendant No. 3, who had prospered, came to his rescue so that the property may be saved. But, apparently, they paid up the debts only in order to get the properties for themselves to the exclusion of the other two sons, namely, Kayyumali, Plaintiff- Respondent, and Nazarali, Defendant No. 4,

facts.text: Kayyumali (Plaintiff-Respondent) and Nazarali (Defendant No. 4) executed deeds on 10-10-1942 acknowledging receipt of cash and movable properties in exchange for relinquishing future rights in specified properties.

anchor.surface_text: who executed, on 10-10-1942, deeds acknowledging receipt of some cash and moveable properties as companysideration for number claiming any rights in future in the properties mentioned in the deeds in which they gave up their possible rights in future. The executant of each deed said I have accordingly taken the things mentioned above as the equivalent of my share and I have out of free will written this.

facts.text: Release deeds are Ex.D/2 (plaintiff) and Ex.D/3 (defendant No. 4).

anchor.surface_text: In the instant case, it is evident that the release deeds Ex.D/2 and Ex.D/3 were executed by the plaintiff and defendant No. 4, Nazarali, when the defendants NO. 1, 2 and 3 had with their labour and money straightened the status of his father Kadar Ali and had cleared up the debts which would have devoured the, whole property of Kadar Ali

facts.text: During Kadir Ali's lifetime, Kayyumali and Nazarali did not object to property dispositions.

anchor.surface_text: During the fathers life-time, when all chance or expectation of inheritance by either Kayyumali or Nazarali companyld be destroyed by disposition of property, neither of these two raised his little finger to object.

facts.text: First Appellate Court found plaintiff and defendant No. 4 estopped from claiming shares due to deeds, conduct, and family settlement context.

anchor.surface_text: The first Appellate Court, the final companyrt on questions of fact, recorded the following findings, after examining the, whole set of facts before it, to companylude that the plaintiff and defendant No. 4 were estopped from claiming their shares in the inheritance In the instant case, it is evident that the release deeds Ex.D/2 and Ex.D/3 were executed by the plaintiff and defendant No. 4, Nazarali,

facts.text: Plaintiff was doing nothing and was a burden to father when deeds executed.

anchor.surface_text: and the plaintiff was doing numberhing and was in a way a burden to his father. In such state of things when the plaintiff and defendant No. 4 executed the release deeds in question, it can be said that it was a family settlement to prevent the future disputes that may arise and to secure the peace and happiness in the family of the parties

facts.text: High Court reproduced first appellate findings without dissent and held consideration passed to plaintiff and D4.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court reproduced the passage, quoted above, from the judgment of the First Appellate Court, without any dissent from any of the findings of fact companytained there. It specifically held that the Court below was companyrect in finding that companysideration had passed the Plaintiff and Defendant No. 4 for the relinquishment of their future possible rights of inheritance.

facts.text: High Court held Muslim law prohibits transfer of chance of inheritance like Section 6(a) TPA, no estoppel.

anchor.surface_text: It proceeded on the assumption that, it the law had number prohibited the transfer of his right of inheritance by a Muslim heir, an estoppel would have operated against the Plaintiff and Defendant No. 4 on the findings given. It held that the rule. of Muslim Personal law on the subject has the same effect as Section 6 a  of the Transfer of Property Act

facts.text: Supreme Court holds plaintiff and D4 estopped by declarations, conduct, silence from claiming shares.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by BEG, J. This is a Defendants appeal by Special Leave against the judgment and decree of the High Court of Madhya Pradesh allowing a second appeal in a partition suit between members of a family governed by Muslim law.

facts.text: Defendants No. 1,2,3 cleared debts with labour and money, improving father's status.

anchor.surface_text: when the defendants NO. 1, 2 and 3 had with their labour and money straightened the status of his father Kadar Ali and had cleared up the debts which would have devoured the, whole property of Kadar Ali

facts.text: Deeds induced defendants 1,2,3 to discharge debts and they became affluent.

anchor.surface_text: and thereby induced the defendants No. 1, 2 and 3 to believe that the plaintiff would number claim a share in the suit properties and led them to discharge the debts due to Kadar All and to be in affluent circumstances themselves as they are at present

facts.text: High Court preferred Madras HC view in Abdul Kafoor v. Abdul Razack over Allahabad view in Latafat Hussain.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court had relied on a decision of the Madras High Court in Abdul Kafoor v. Abdul Razack l , which had been A.I.R. 1959 Mad. p. 131. followed by the Kerala High Court without giving fresh reason in Valanhivil Kunchi v. Kengayil Pattikavil Kunbi Avulla 1  in preference to the view adopted by the Allahabad High Court in Latafat Hussain v. Hidayat Hussain 2

facts.text: Supreme Court prefers Allahabad view, holds estoppel applies despite Muslim law rule on spes successionis.

anchor.surface_text: As we are clearly of opinion that there is numberhing in law to bar the application of the principle of estoppel, companytained in Section 115 of the Evidence Act, against the plaintiff and Defendant No. 4, upon the totality of facts found by the final Court of facts,

facts.text: Supreme Court allows appeal, sets aside High Court judgment, restores first Appellate Court decree.

anchor.surface_text: The result is that we allow this appeal, set aside the judg- ment and the decree of the High Court, and restore that of the first Appellate Court. In the circumstances of this case, we order that the parties will bear their own companyts.

facts.text: Plaintiff seeks partition shares in properties covered by deeds.

anchor.surface_text: The only question before us number is whether the Plaintiff and Defendant No. 4 are estopped by their declarations and companyduct and silence from claiming their shares in the properties companyered by these deeds.

arguments.claim: Rule of Mahomedan law does not recognise purported transfer of spes successionis not as prohibition but to clarify transferable rights; purpose not to protect recipients of consideration

anchor.surface_text: The object however, of the rule of Mahomedan law which does not recognise a purported transfer of a spes succession is as a legally valid transfer at all, is not to prohibit anything but only to make it clear what is and what is not a transferable right or interest in property just as this is what section 6 a  of Transfer of Property Act is meant to do.

arguments.claim: Renunciation of expectancy not struck by Section 23 Indian Contract Act as no transfer but future contract/conduct

anchor.surface_text: With due respect, we are unable to concur with the view of the Madras High Court that renunciation of an expectancy, as a purported but legally ineffective transfer, is struck by Section 23 of the Indian Contract Act. As it would be void as a transfer at all there was no need to rely on Section 23 Contract Act,

arguments.claim: Declarations in deeds and course of conduct create estoppel as rule of evidence under equitable principles

anchor.surface_text: The real question was whether quite apart from any transfer or contract, the declarations in the deeds of purported relinquishment and receipt of valuable consideration could not be parts of a course of conduct over a number of years which, taken as a whole, created a, bar against a successful assertion of a right to property when that right actually came into being.

arguments.claim: Under Muslim law nemo est heres viventis; bare renunciation invalid but conduct with consideration creates estoppel

anchor.surface_text: Sir Roland Wilson, in his Anglo Mohhamadan Law  P 260, paragraph 208  states the position thus - For the sake of those, readers Who are familiar with the joint ownership of father and son according to the most widely prevalent school of Hindu Law, it is perhaps desirable to state explicitly that in Muhammadan, as in Roman and English Law, nemo est heres viventis-a living person has, no heir.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Totality of facts found by lower courts (deeds, conduct, silence, consideration received) accepted; S.115 Evidence Act applies as rule of evidence; Muslim law non-transferability does not bar estoppel.

precedents.citation: Hurmoot-Ool-Nisa Begum v. Allehdia Khan,   is explained by Ameer Ali According to the Mahomedan Law the right of inheritance may be renounced and such renunciation need number be express but may be implied from the ceasing or desisting from prosecuting a claim maintainable against another.  1  1871 17 W.R.P.C. 108

anchor.surface_text: Hurmoot-Ool-Nisa Begum v. Allehdia Khan,   is explained by Ameer Ali According to the Mahomedan Law the right of inheritance may be renounced and such renunciation need number be express but may be implied from the ceasing or desisting from prosecuting a claim maintainable against another. Ameer Ali explained, citing an opinion of the law officers, given in Khanum Jan v. Jan Bibi  2

precedents.cited_proposition: right of inheritance may be renounced expressly or impliedly by ceasing to prosecute claim

anchor.surface_text: Ameer Ali explained, citing an opinion of the law officers, given in Khanum Jan v. Jan Bibi  2 .lm15 Renunciation implies the yielding up of a right already vested, or the ceasing or desisting from prosecuting a claim maintainable against another. It is evident that, during the life-time of the mother the daughters have numberright of inheritance and their claim on that account is number maintainable against any person during her life-time.

precedents.cited_proposition: renunciation implies yielding vested right or desisting from maintainable claim; no right during lifetime

precedents.citation: Mohammad Ali. Khan v. Bisar Ali Khan, 1  the Oudh Chief Court has relied upon Hurmoot-Ool-Nisa Begums. case  supra  to hold that according to Mahomedan Law there may be renunciation of the right to inheritance and such renunciation need number be express but may be implied from the ceasing or desisting from prosecuting a ,claim maintainable against another. A.I.R. 1928 Oudh 67.

anchor.surface_text: Incidentally, we may observe that, in Mohammad Ali. Khan v. Bisar Ali Khan, 1  the Oudh Chief Court has relied upon Hurmoot-Ool-Nisa Begums. case  supra  to hold that according to Mahomedan Law there may be renunciation of the right to inheritance and such renunciation need number be express but may be implied from the ceasing or desisting from prosecuting a ,claim maintainable against another. A.I.R. 1928 Oudh 67.

precedents.case_name: Mohammad Ali Khan v. Bisar Ali Khan
precedents.cited_proposition: renunciation of inheritance right under Mahomedan law may be implied from conduct
